officialLinks.name: Air China — Pets as Checked Baggage
Air China — Passengers with a Hearing/Visual Impairment (service dogs in cabin)

sourceDates.note: Page states: Starting February 1, 2025, temporary suspension of transporting dogs to the U.S.
No explicit last-updated date; footer shows 2025 copyright.

policyFindings: Air China accepts only domesticated cats and dogs as pets; they are carried as checked baggage only; no in-cabin pets permitted.

In-cabin exception: only trained service dogs (guide/hearing dogs) for passengers with visual/hearing impairments; request at least 48 hours before departure; passenger must be 16+ if traveling alone; dog must wear a service-dog vest and leash; provide required passenger ID and the dog’s valid quarantine and vaccination certificates at booking and check-in; no fee for service dogs; if checked, the dog and its container/food are carried free and do not affect baggage allowance.

U.S. embargo: starting 2025-02-01, Air China temporarily suspends transportation of all dogs (including guide/hearing dogs) on flights to the United States; change/refund offered for affected bookings.
Checked pets eligibility: only cats and dogs; not accepted: aggressive or brachycephalic breeds, pregnant or nursing animals, animals under 8 weeks old, within 7 days post-birth, or sick animals.
Reservation: you must apply when making the reservation; carriage only after Air China approval.

Quantity/weight/time: maximum one pet per passenger; pet plus container/food/water must not exceed 32 kg; present at the airport and check in the pet at least 120 minutes before departure; sign a liability waiver on the baggage tag.

Aircraft/operational limits: pets are carried only in oxygen-equipped cargo holds; A319, A320, 737-8 MAX, and ARJ21-700 cannot transport pets; no interline pet transport; pets are not accepted on wet-leased flights.
Fees for pets as special baggage per container: 2–8 kg USD 600; >8–23 kg USD 800; >23–32 kg USD 1,200.

Crate requirements: airline-approved sturdy crates; pet must be able to stand, turn, and lie naturally; materials limited to fiberglass, metal, rigid plastic, welded mesh, or hardwood; welded metal door with proper hinges/locks plus an external secondary door seal; ventilation on three sides (upper third) totaling at least 16% of wall area with mesh-covered openings; solid floor with absorbent bedding; fixed water container refillable without opening the crate; food container fixed/attached.
Breed restrictions examples (not exhaustive): bulldogs, pugs, boxers, various terriers/spaniels/mastiffs; for cats: Persian, Himalayan, Burmese, Exotic Shorthair.

Documentation: domestic China flights require an AQSIQ quarantine certificate; international/regional flights require the AQSIQ certificate plus compliance with entry/exit/transit country rules; for pets entering China: ISO 11784/11785 microchip, rabies vaccination, and quarantine rules per China Customs.
Emotional support animals are not recognized as service animals; only guide/hearing dogs may travel in the cabin; others are treated as pets under the checked-baggage policy.
Cargo shipments are not covered on the passenger-site pet policy; no interline transport; contact Air China Cargo for freight options.
notes: Research started from the seed URL and followed the internal Fee schedules and service dogs directions; the Disabled Passengers portal link was blocked by Incapsula, so the accessible Passengers with a Hearing/Visual Impairment page on the U.S. site was used for the in-cabin service-dog rules.
The fee schedule document is labeled 1 Jun 2019 Edition, but it remains the fee reference linked from the current U.S. pet-policy page. Consider confirming fees directly with Air China at booking.

Critical U.S. notice: As of February 1, 2025, Air China temporarily suspends transportation of all dogs to the United States, including service dogs. Verify status when planning travel to/from the U.S. since this affects both checked pets and in-cabin service dogs.
The one pet per aircraft cap (from the Chinese checked-baggage page) can make space extremely limited; secure approval early and consider alternate dates/routes if needed.

For U.S. itineraries involving dogs, Air China’s posted suspension effective February 1, 2025 means dogs (including service dogs) cannot be accepted to the United States on Air China until the notice is updated; verify status at booking.
Because certain aircraft (A319/A320/737-8 MAX/ARJ21-700) cannot carry pets, check your specific flight’s aircraft type; equipment swaps can affect acceptance.

Fees are substantial and are assessed per container weight bracket, separate from free baggage allowance; budget USD 600–1,200 each way for 2–32 kg; confirm at booking, as fees may change without notice.

If your pet plus carrier exceeds 32 kg, Air China will not accept it as checked baggage; you may need to explore cargo options. The passenger-site guidance does not detail pet-as-cargo procedures—contact Air China directly for cargo solutions.

draft.PetPolicySummary: Pets as Checked Baggage: Air China only accepts domesticated cats and dogs as checked baggage; no pets are allowed in the cabin. Aggressive breeds, snub-nosed (brachycephalic) breeds, pregnant pets, pets less than 8 weeks old, nursing pets, pets that have given birth within 7 days, or sick animals are not accepted. Certain aircraft models (A319, A320, 737-8 MAX, ARJ21-700) lack oxygen-equipped cargo compartments and cannot transport pets. Passengers are fully liable for their pets, and Air China is not responsible for illness, injury, or death unless related to airline negligence. Carriage Requirements: Pets must be pre-approved for transport when reservations are made. Only one pet per passenger is allowed, and the total weight (including the container, food, and water) must not exceed 32 kg. Passengers must check in their pets at least 120 minutes before departure and sign a liability waiver. Fees (per container, one way): 2–8 kg USD 600; >8–23 kg USD 800; >23–32 kg USD 1,200 (confirm at booking; fees may change). Transport Documents: Domestic flights within China require a quarantine certificate from AQSIQ. International flights require AQSIQ certification and compliance with the destination/transit country’s regulations. Quarantine Requirements (entering China): Pets must meet China Customs regulations, including valid quarantine and rabies vaccination certificates and ISO 11784/11785-compliant microchips; a 30-day quarantine may apply with certain exemptions for designated origins or qualified guide/hearing/search-and-rescue dogs. Pet Carrier Requirements: Carriers must meet specific material and structural requirements, including adequate ventilation, solid floors, wire-mesh-covered openings, and secure locking mechanisms; dimensions must allow the pet to stand, turn, and lie down naturally; food/water containers must be fixed and water refillable from outside. U.S. Notice: Effective February 1, 2025, Air China has temporarily suspended transportation of all dogs to the United States, including service dogs; verify status before travel. Transportation of Service Dogs: Trained service dogs for passengers with qualifying disabilities may travel in the cabin when requirements are met (fees waived); U.S.-bound flights are subject to the dog suspension noted above. For full details, contact Air China or consult official notices.
draft.ImprovedPetPolicySummary:
Air China Pet Policy Summary

  • Acceptance: Only domesticated cats and dogs; pets are transported as checked baggage only (no in-cabin pets).
  • Not accepted: Aggressive breeds, snub-nosed (brachycephalic) breeds, pregnant/nursing pets, pets < 8 weeks old, pets within 7 days post-birth, or sick animals.
  • Aircraft limits: No pet carriage on A319, A320, 737-8 MAX, ARJ21-700 (cargo holds lack oxygen).
  • Booking/limits: Prior approval required at reservation. Max 1 pet per passenger. Max total weight (pet + container + food/water) 32 kg.
  • Airport: Check in the pet ≥ 120 minutes before departure and sign a liability waiver.
  • Fees (per container, one way): 2–8 kg USD 600; >8–23 kg USD 800; >23–32 kg USD 1,200. Confirm at booking.
  • Documents: Domestic China—AQSIQ quarantine certificate. International/regional—AQSIQ certificate plus compliance with all entry/exit/transit rules.
  • Entering China: ISO 11784/11785 microchip, valid rabies vaccination/quarantine certificates; 30-day quarantine may apply unless exempt (designated origins or qualified guide/hearing/search-and-rescue dogs).
  • Crates: Airline-approved, sturdy, ventilated on three sides (upper third), solid floor, mesh-covered openings, secure metal door/locks; pet must be able to stand, turn, and lie naturally; fixed water container refillable from outside.
  • U.S. notice: From Feb 1, 2025, Air China temporarily suspends transport of all dogs to the United States (includes service dogs). Verify current status before travel.
  • Service dogs: Trained guide/hearing dogs may travel in-cabin when requirements are met (no fee). Emotional support animals are not recognized as service animals.

Always confirm requirements and fees with Air China before travel; policies and operational limits can change without notice.
draft.inCompartmentDetails: Air China does not accept pets (cats/dogs) in the cabin. Only trained service dogs for passengers with qualifying disabilities may be carried in-cabin; all other pets must travel as checked baggage.
draft.carrierCompartmentDetails:
Compartment Carrier Details

Not accepted: Cats and dogs that are pregnant, under 8 weeks old, nursing, have given birth within 7 days, or are sick.
China quarantine requirements

Based on Announcement No. 5 [2019] of the General Administration of Customs of China.

  • Only cats or dogs (including service dogs) allowed. One pet per person.
  • Must provide valid quarantine certificates and rabies vaccination certificates from official agencies.
  • Pets must have ISO 11784/11785 compliant microchips (15-digit numeric code). - If not compliant, owner must provide their own compatible reader.
  • Pets must undergo 30-day quarantine at designated China Customs facilities unless exempt (see below).
Exemptions from 30-day quarantine
  • Designated countries/territories: Pets from 19 specific regions (e.g., New Zealand, Australia, UK, Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, Macau, etc.) → If microchipped and pass on-site quarantine.
  • Non-designated countries: Allowed if microchipped, pass on-site quarantine, and provide a valid rabies antibody test (≥ 0.5 IU/ml, from an approved lab).
  • Guide dogs, hearing dogs, search/rescue dogs: Allowed if microchipped, pass on-site quarantine, and owner presents valid user + training certificates.
Pet container requirements
  • Pets requiring quarantine must arrive through ports equipped with quarantine facilities.
  • The General Administration of Customs of China publishes an updated list of such ports on its official website.
draft.carrierCargoDetails:
In Cargo Carrier Details

Aircraft limits: Pets cannot be transported in cargo on A319 / A320 / 737-8 MAX / ARJ21-700 (no oxygen supply in some cargo holds).
Key rules
  • One pet may be checked per passenger.
  • Max weight: 32 kg (70 lb) total including carrier, food, and water.
  • Check-in deadline: Arrive and complete pet check-in ≥ 120 minutes before departure.
  • You must sign a liability waiver on the back of the baggage tag at check-in.
  • No interline service: Not available with other airlines.
  • Customs notice: If entry rules are not met, pets may be repatriated or destroyed by Customs; the airline is not liable.
Fees
  • Per container, one way: 2–8 kg: USD 600; >8–23 kg: USD 800; >23–32 kg: USD 1,200. Confirm at booking; fees may change.
Pet carrier requirements
  • Use an air-travel approved carrier, secured properly. For detachable roofs, all latches, nuts, bolts must be present and intact.
  • Door security: Add an extra external lock (e.g., cable tie/clip) that does not harm the pet.
  • Carrier must be acceptable to Air China; non-compliant carriers will be refused.
Prohibited carrier features (not accepted):
  • Fiberglass or hard plastic doors.
  • Openings/holes large enough for paws or nose to protrude.
  • Roof doors or ventilation holes at the bottom ends of side walls.
  • Side openings/vents adjacent to the main door that are not covered with wire mesh.
Dimensions
  • Contact Air China in advance to confirm carrier fits aircraft door and hold capacity.
  • Carrier must allow the pet to stand, turn around, and lie down naturally.
Materials
  • Allowed: fiberglass, metal, rigid plastic, welded mesh, hardwood.
  • Not suitable: containers made entirely of welded mesh or wire solder.
Ventilation
  • Holes in the upper third of the walls on three sides (excluding the door).
  • At least 16% of total wall surface area must be ventilation.
  • Extra holes may be added on the top/sides as needed.
  • All openings must be wire-mesh covered to prevent paws/nose from extending out.
Doors & handling
  • Door forms one end of the container and must have a sliding chain or hinge lock.
  • Doors must be welded metal, strong enough to resist bending/damage.
  • Plastic-shell carriers: door must have ≥ 1.6 cm top/bottom protuberances for hinges/locking pins.
  • Spacer bars/handles should be fitted along the mid-outer walls on both sides for handling and protection.
Floors
  • Solid floor to prevent leakage; provide absorbent bedding (no straw).
Roofs
  • Solid roof; ventilation across the roof is allowed if it does not reduce structural integrity.
Food & water
  • Carrier must have a fixed water container that can be refilled from outside without opening the door.
  • Feed containers must be fixed inside or firmly attached; you may attach food externally for possible delays.

draft.serviceAnimalDetails:
Service Animals (In-Cabin & Support)

Starting February 1, 2025, Air China will temporarily suspend the transportation of dogs, including guide and hearing dogs traveling with disabled passengers, on flights to the United States.

Service dogs are specially trained to assist disabled individuals, including guide dogs and hearing dogs. Emotional comfort dogs are not considered service dogs and must follow small animal transport rules.

  • Passengers with visual or auditory disabilities traveling with service dogs in-cabin must be at least 16 years old.
  • Service dogs must have the following certificates presented at ticket purchase and travel:
    • Valid official quarantine certificates, rabies vaccination certificates, and professional training certificates issued by the departure, transit, or destination country.
    • Valid microchips when entering China or on international/regional transit domestic flights.
  • Passengers should verify quarantine regulations of entry-exit countries in advance to ensure compliance.
  • If a dog transport booking to the U.S. was made before the suspension, ticket changes or refunds are available.
  • Reservations for service dogs must be made through Air China ticket offices or authorized agents at least 48 hours before departure.

Check-in

  • Arrive at the check-in counter with the service dog at least 120 minutes before departure.
  • No additional fees apply for service dogs meeting boarding requirements.
  • If checked, service dogs travel free of charge with container and food; their weight does not count toward baggage allowance.
  • Disabled passengers with service dogs cannot occupy emergency exit seats or upper cabin seats on Boeing B747 aircraft.
  • Terminal assistance is provided for disabled passengers with service dogs unless restricted by local authorities.

In-flight Service

  • Support is provided to disabled passengers traveling alone with service dogs as much as possible.
  • Assistance with eating, toileting, excretory functions on seats, or medical services is not provided.
  • Service dogs must wear a work shirt and towing rope during boarding; mouthpieces may be waived with passenger consent.
  • Service dogs must not occupy seats, run freely, or disturb other passengers.
  • Passengers are responsible for their service dog's excretion and maintaining cabin hygiene.
  • Passengers bear liability for any injury or damage caused by their service dogs.
  • There are limits on the number of disabled passengers with service dogs per aircraft; early booking is advised.
Air China may refuse transport of service dogs if:
  • The dog poses a direct threat to health or safety of others.
  • The dog causes serious interference in the cabin or airport.
  • Transport violates government regulations or requirements.
Written explanations will be provided within 10 days if transport is refused.
